ANTHROPIC:
 CEO SAYS AI WILL CAUSE INEVITABLE DISRUPTION; COMPANY NEEDS FEWER SOFTWARE ENGINEERS
Anthropic CEO said technological disruption is inevitable, though not necessarily limited to any one industry.
He stated that even within Anthropic, the company now needs fewer software engineers than before.
He added it is difficult to determine whether jobs will disappear entirely or be down-scaled or shifted into different roles.

La Opala Q3 FY26 -

Revenue has been declining for 3 straight years, still EBITDA margins expanded 37% vs 32.6% in FY25. Madhupur plant closure has lowered fixed cost substantially (COGS dropped from 33% to 18% YoY). 

With current asset base, peak revenue potential is ~450 Cr but current demand scenario looks bleak. Exports are weak, domestic demand is soft and more competitors are putting up capacities (Milton just came up with new capacity). 

Demand recovery seems back ended and capital allocation story is yet to improve.

AI Summit â€˜Show-Stealerâ€™ Robot Sparks Made-in-India Controversy

A robotic dog named â€œOrionâ€ became a crowd-puller at the India AI Impact Summit, showcased at the stall of Galgotias University.

The quadruped robot was introduced as a creation of the universityâ€™s Centre of Excellence and was widely seen as a Made-in-India innovation.

However, online users quickly identified the robot as the Unitree Go2, a commercially available product made by Unitree Robotics and sold globally for around $2,800.

Social media fact-checking triggered controversy, raising questions about whether a made-in-China product had been presented as an indigenous innovation.

Authorities reportedly asked the university to vacate the stall, while the institution maintained it had not explicitly claimed the robot was made in India.

The episode cast an awkward spotlight on the summit, which aimed to celebrate Indiaâ€™s indigenous AI capabilities and global ambitions.

FED MINUTES SUMMARY (Jan 27-28 Meeting)

Inflation Expectations  
- Participants anticipate inflation declining toward 2% target.  
- Pace and timing remain uncertain.  
- Most cautioned progress could be slower and more uneven than expected.  
- Risk of persistent above-target inflation seen as meaningful.

Rate Policy Outlook  
- Several participants view further rate cuts appropriate if inflation falls in line with expectations.

Staff Economic Forecast  
- Economic activity outlook stronger than December projection.  
- Inflation forecast slightly higher.  
- Unemployment to decline gradually from 2026 onward.

Growth and Labor View  
- Economic activity expanding at solid pace, expected to continue in 2026.  
- Vast majority see labor market stabilizing with diminished downside risks.  
- Labor market likely to stabilize then improve this year with appropriate policy.

Carlton swings from VIP to Safari!

In an interesting development on the Indian bourses, Safari Industries has announced a 20 year licensing agreement with Carlton Retail to exclusively use the â€œCarltonâ€ brand in India for luggage and accessories.

This comes after the long running trademark dispute between VIP Industries and Carlton Shoes over ownership of the Carlton name in India. The court had barred VIP from using the brand for its luggage line in the domestic market. Safari is now set to retail backpacks and luggage under the Carlton brand.

For context, Carlton contributed about 4 to 6% of VIPâ€™s FY25 turnover, translating to roughly â‚¹130 cr.

Key agreement details
* Initial term of 20 years with an option to renew for another 20 years at Safariâ€™s discretion
* License fee of â‚¹45 lakh annually or 5% of net sales, whichever is higher
* Interest free refundable security deposit of â‚¹100 cr to be paid to Carlton Retail in tranches

Why this could matter for Safari?
1ï¸âƒ£ Firmer presence in the premium segment through an established global brand. Carlton can complement Safari Select & Urban Jungle & help Safari compete more effectively with players like Samsonite, Mokobara & Delsey.
2ï¸âƒ£ Safariâ€™s premium portfolio currently contributes only about 6% of revenue. Scaling Carlton could accelerate premium mix improvement and support margins, given the higher price realisations in this segment.

Execution and brand positioning will be the key monitorables from here.

In 2004, Carlton partnered VIP when Sudhir Jatia was part of the company. In a full circle development, Carlton has now entered into a new agreement with Safari Industries India Ltd. which Jatia currently owns.

Extended Winter Delays Summer Sales Cycle for Consumer Companies

A prolonged winter and leftover inventory from last year have delayed the summer sales cycle by over 45 days, impacting consumer goods and AC manufacturers.

Peak company-to-trade sales have not yet begun even in southern markets, which typically lead the season.

Summer trade loading, which usually starts mid-January, is now expected closer to Holi.

Retailers are cautious, still carrying 4â€“6 weeks of unsold inventory from last yearâ€™s cool summer.

Companies such as Blue Star and Dabur India expect demand recovery supported by GST cuts, pent-up demand, and a warmer forecast.

Prices of ACs and appliances may rise due to higher copper and steel costs and rupee depreciation.

For summer-focused firms, the season can contribute 40â€“45% of annual sales, making the delayed start significant.

Hindustan Unilever noted that while winter products performed well, summer portfolio growth has been relatively subdued so far.

India AI Impact Summit 2026 â€” Day 1 just wrapped. Here's what actually matters:

1/ The first global AI summit in the Global South kicked off at Bharat Mandapam. 600+ startups, 300+ pavilions, 13 country pavilions. PM Modi inaugurated and toured booths from Sarvam AI, HCLTech, Jio, and dozens of startups.

2/ The big launch: India's sovereign AI models are here.
BharatGen unveiled Param2 â€” 17B parameter, 22 Indian languages, Mixture of Experts architecture. Built by IIT Bombay-led consortium under DST. Not a demo. MahaGPT is already deployed with the Maharashtra government.

3/ Sarvam AI went voice-first â€” launched Sarvam Vision, Bulbul V3, and Sarvam Arya. Their thesis: India's AI future isn't English-first, it's vernacular-first. Hard to argue with that.

4/ Yotta's CEO teased a big GPU expansion announcement with Nvidia coming in the next couple of days. They've already deployed ~10,000 GPUs. India's compute story is scaling fast.

5/ The hot takes were sharp:
â€” Vinod Khosla: IT/BPO services will "almost completely disappear" in 5 years
â€” HCL's Vineet Nayar: "You must be dreaming if you think AI will generate employment"
â€” Info Edge's Sanjeev Bikhchandani: Learn 10-15 AI tools or fall behind

6/ Global players are betting on India:
Anthropic opened its first India office (Bengaluru) â€” India is #2 market for Claude
AMD partnered with TCS on rack-scale AI infra via their "Helios" platform
Qualcomm pitched hybrid on-device + cloud AI deployment

7/ The expo floor was packed with real use-cases â€” precision farming, sign language translation gloves, AI for special needs education, digital safety tools, and Tata's rural women empowerment program.
Not slides. Working products.

8/ India's AI play isn't about building the next GPT-5. It's about deploying AI at population scale, in 22 languages, for problems that global models weren't designed for.

Day 1 made that very clear. Watching Day 2 closely.

IRDAI-Life Insurers Meet: CEOs Propose Deferred Commissions Amid Cost Cuts

Key Proposals  
Deferred Model  
- CEOs suggest deferring 40-50% front-loaded commissions over 5 years.  
- Applies to all distributors: agents, corporates, brokers, banks.  

Commission Caps  
- Absolute commissions reduced by 10%.  
- Aligns incentives with policy persistency, cuts acquisition costs.  

IRDAI Action  
- Seeks 3-yr distributor-wise commission data by Feb 23.  
- Follows scrutiny on high payouts vs mutual funds/pensions.  

Industry Context  
- Life insurers submitted deferred proposals; group business pending.  
- IRDAI pushes affordability post-GST zero on life/health premiums.  
- Recent fines e.g. Reliance Gen for disguised commissions.  

Market Impact  
- PB Fintech/Insurance stocks watch: Potential margin pressure short-term.  
- Long-term: Cleaner distribution, lower mis-selling, higher penetration.  

Key Takeaway  
Deferred commissions curb front-loading, boost affordability; IRDAI data call signals reforms ahead, positive for sector health.
